title: 106_hr4730
content: The Act may be cited as the "Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia Recognition Act". The Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia, descendants of the original Creek Indian Nation, are recognized as political successors to the signatories of the 1832 Treaty of Washington. With over 2,500 eligible members residing close to their ancestral homeland in Georgia, they are acknowledged under the "Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia Recognition Act". The Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia, descendants of the original Creek Indian Nation, are recognized as political successors to the signatories of the 1832 Treaty of Washington. They declined removal under the treaty and continue to operate as a sovereign tribe with a viable tribal government. In 1972, they petitioned for Federal recognition but faced challenges due to lack of education and financial resources. The Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia faced challenges in obtaining Federal recognition due to lack of education and financial resources, leading to technical omissions in their petition. As a result, the petition was denied in 1981. Despite this, the Federal Government, the government of the State of Georgia, and local governments have recognized the Tribe's political leaders as leaders of a distinct political entity. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "member" refers to an enrolled member of the Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia or an individual placed on the membership rolls according to this Act. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The term "Tribe" refers to the Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia. SEC. 4. FEDERAL RECOGNITION. Federal recognition is extended to the Tribe, making them eligible for all Federal benefits and services available to federally recognized Indian tribes. The Indian Reorganization Act of 1934 is applicable to the Tribe and its members. SEC. 5. RESERVATION. The Tribe can transfer land to the Secretary for trust within 2 years, establishing it as the initial reservation land with a prohibition on gaming. SEC. 6. BASE MEMBERSHIP ROLL. SEC. 6. BASE MEMBERSHIP ROLL. The Tribe must submit a membership roll to the Secretary within 120 days of the Act's enactment, based on the Tribe's Constitution and Bill of Rights. Future membership is limited to lineal descendants of individuals on the base roll who maintain political relations with the Tribe. SEC. 7. JURISDICTION. The reservation established by this Act will be considered Indian country under Federal and tribal jurisdiction. SEC. 8. TREATIES NOT AFFECTED. This Act will not amend, modify, or interpret any treaty involving a tribe mentioned in the Act, preserving all rights secured by such treaties.
